title: Life Without Light: Creatures in the Dark With Sarah McAnulty

last_post.content:
In the dark deep sea, sperm whales use echolocation to find food.

Their echolocation clicks are *loud*. 230 decibels loud. How loud is that? Well, loud enough that if a sound wave of 230 decibels hit ya, you'd be dead 😳

Want to learn more about how animals live in the dark?
👀

You do?? Well you're in luck because I'm teaching a class this summer starting June 20th that's all about Life in the Dark.

I'm rabies vaccinated. Let's go.

4 weeks, $75
https://www.atlasobscura.com/experiences/nocturnal-animals-course

It is considered an official Census Bureau package as it is available from the CB's github https://github.com/uscensusbureau/cvam. BookCorpus, a dataset ubiquitous in training LLMs (incl. OpenAI) was found to contain only *7,185* unique works, all from a single source, which is smashwords[dot]com ¹ ²
__
¹ paper : https://arxiv.org/abs/2105.05241
² summary : https://towardsdatascience.com/dirty-secrets-of-bookcorpus-a-key-dataset-in-machine-learning-6ee2927e8650

title: The unreasonable effectiveness of few-shot learning for machine translation

last_post.content:
For people that say that LLMs "don't really understand" language.

How do you explain this?

"The unreasonable effectiveness of few-shot learning for machine translation" trains a model on text from different languages - NOT explicitly translated. It's never given matching pairs of the same text in two languages.

Just given about 5 example translations on the prompt, the model is then able to match the performance of state of the art specialized translation systems.

https://arxiv.org/abs/2302.01398
